Fundamental Analysis¶

Fundamental analysis assesses a company by looking at its financial statements to evaluate its health and value, and compares them across time and against competitors.

Financial Statements¶

Balance Sheet¶

It’s a snapshot.

fundamental_analysis.financial_statements_entries.cash_and_cash_equivalents(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q')¶

Cash and Cash Equivalents is the amount of money on deposit in the bank. It is composed of

  • Cash: ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]). t

    icker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]). ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • Short-term investments:

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

Income Statement¶

Cash Flow Statement¶

Intermediary Metrics¶

Accounting Ratios¶

Liquidity Ratios¶

These ratios measure the availability of cash to pay debt.

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.current_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q') → float¶

The current ratio measures a company’s ability to pay off short-term liabilities with current assets.

  • Category: Liquidity Ratio

  • Healthy Range: between 1.2 and 2

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Current Ratio} = \frac{\text{Current Assets}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.acid_test_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q')¶

The acid-test ratio (or quick ratio) measures a company’s ability to pay off short-term liabilities with quick assets

  • Category: Liquidity Ratio

  • Healthy Range:

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Acid-Test Ratio} = \frac{\text{Liquid Assets}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.cash_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q')¶

The cash ratio measures a company’s ability to pay off short-term liabilities with cash and cash equivalents

  • Category: Liquidity Ratio

  • Healthy Range:

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Cash Ratio} = \frac{\text{Cash and Cash equivalents + Current Marketable Securities}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.operating_cash_flow_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q')¶

The operating cash flow ratio is a measure of the number of times a company can pay off current liabilities with the cash generated in a given period

  • Category: Liquidity Ratio

  • Healthy Range:

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Operating Cash Flow Ratio} = \frac{\text{Operating Cash Flow}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\]

Activity (Efficiency) Ratios¶

These ratios measure how quickly a firm converts non-cash assets to cash assets.

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.degree_of_operating_leverage(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Degree of Operating Leverage} = \frac{\text{}}{\text{}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.asset_turnover_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The asset turnover ratio measures a company’s ability to generate sales from assets.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Asset Turnover Ratio} = \frac{\text{Net Sales}}{\text{Total Assets}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.accounts_payables_turnover_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The accounts payables turnover ratio measures the number of times the company pays off all its creditors in one year.

  • Category: Efficiency (Activity) Ratio

  • Subcategory: Accounts Payable

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Accounts Payables Turnover Ratio} = \frac{\text{Cost of Goods Sold}}{\text{Average Accounts Payable}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.payables_conversion_period(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY', number_of_days=365)¶

The payables conversion period, or Days Payable Outstanding (DPO), is the average number of days of payables. For instance, a conversion period of 30 means that on average, the company takes 30 days to pay its creditors. It is an element of the cash conversion cycle.

  • Category: Efficiency (Activity) Ratio

  • Subcategory: Accounts Payable

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • number_of_days – Number of days in period. By default the period is 365 days, but some analysts use 360.

Returns

\[\text{Payables Conversion Period} = \frac{\text{365}}{\text{Payables Turnover}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.inventory_turnover_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The inventory (or stock) turnover ratio measures how many times a company’s inventory is sold and replaced over a given period

  • Category: Efficiency (Activity) Ratio

  • Subcategory: Inventory

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Inventory Turnover Ratio} = \frac{\text{Cost of Goods Sold}}{\text{Average Inventory}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.inventory_conversion_period(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY', number_of_days=365)¶

The inventory conversion period, or days inventory outstanding (DIO), measures the average number of days that a company holds on to inventory before selling it to customers. It is an element of the cash conversion cycle.

  • Category: Efficiency (Activity) Ratio

  • Subcategory: Inventory

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • number_of_days – Number of days in period. By default the period is 365 days, but some analysts use 360.

Returns

\[\text{Inventory Conversion Period} = \frac{\text{365}}{\text{Inventory Turnover}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.accounts_receivables_turnover_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The accounts receivable turnover ratio measures how many times a company can turn receivables into cash over a given period

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Accounts Receivables Turnover Ratio} = \frac{\text{Net Credit Sales}}{\text{Accounts Receivables}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.average_collection_period(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY', number_of_days=365)¶

The average collection period, or Days Sales Outstanding (DSO), represents the average number of days between the date a credit sale is made and the date the purchaser pays for that sale. It is an element of the cash conversion cycle.

  • Category: Efficiency (Activity) Ratio

  • Subcategory: Accounts Receivables

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • number_of_days – Number of days in period. By default the period is 365 days, but some analysts use 360.

Returns

\[\text{Average Collection Period} = \frac{\text{365}}{\text{Accounts Receivables Turnover Ratio}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.cash_conversion_cycle(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The cash conversion cycle (CCC) is a metric that expresses the time (measured in days) it takes for a company to convert its investments in inventory and other resources into cash flows from sales

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Cash Conversion Cycle} = \text{Days Inventory Outstanding} + \text{Days Sales Outstanding} + \text{Days Payable Outstanding}\]

Profitability Ratios¶

These ratios measure the firm’s use of its assets and control of its expenses to generate an acceptable rate of return. Profitability ratios measure a company’s ability to generate income relative to revenue, balance sheet assets, operating costs, and equity.

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.gross_profit_margin(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The gross margin ratio compares the gross profit of a company to its net sales to show how much profit a company makes after paying its cost of goods sold

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Gross Margin Ratio} = \frac{\text{Gross Profit}}{\text{Net Sales}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.net_profit_margin(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Net Profit Margin} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Net Sales}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.operating_profit_margin(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The operating margin ratio compares the operating income of a company to its net sales to determine operating efficiency

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Operating Margin Ratio} = \frac{\text{Operating Income}}{\text{Net Sales}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.return_on_assets(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The return on assets ratio measures how efficiently a company is using its assets to generate profit

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Return on Assets} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Assets}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.return_on_equity(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

The return on equity ratio measures how efficiently a company is using its equity to generate profit

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Return on Equity} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Shareholder’s equity}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.return_on_net_assets(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Return on Net Assets} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Fixed Assets + Working Capital}}\]

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • invested_capital_operating_approach –

Returns

\[\text{Return on Invested Capital} = \frac{\text{NOPAT}}{\text{Invested Capital}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.return_on_capital_employed(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.cash_flow_return_on_investment(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Cash Flow Return on Investment} = \frac{\text{Cash Flow}}{\text{Market Recapitalisation}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.efficiency_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Efficiency Ratio} = \frac{\text{Non-Interest Expense}}{\text{Revenue}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.net_gearing(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{Net Gearing} = \frac{\text{Net Debt}}{\text{Equity}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.basic_earnings_power(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶
Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns

\[\text{} = \frac{\text{}}{\text{}}\]

Market Ratios¶

These ratios measure investor response to owning a company’s stock and also the cost of issuing stock.

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.dividend_payout_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = '', deduct_preferred_dividends: bool = True, use_augmented_ratio: bool = False)¶

The dividend payout ratio is the fraction of net income a firm pays to its stockholders in dividends. The part of earnings not paid to investors is retained i.e. left for investment to provide for future earnings growth. :param stock: ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]). :param date: Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now(). :param lookback_period: lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90). :param period: ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months. :param deduct_preferred_dividends: :param use_augmented_ratio: Some companies choose stock buybacks as an alternative to dividends; in such cases this ratio becomes less meaningful. The augmented ratio adds Buybacks to the Dividends in the numerator. :return: .. math:: text{Dividend Payout Ratio} = frac{text{Dividends}}{text{Net Income}}

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.retention_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY', deduct_preferred_dividends: bool = True, use_augmented_ratio: bool = False)¶

The retention ratio indicates the percentage of a company’s earnings that are not paid out in dividends but credited to retained earnings. It is the opposite of the dividend payout ratio

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • deduct_preferred_dividends –

  • use_augmented_ratio – Some companies choose stock buybacks as an alternative to dividends; in such cases this ratio becomes less meaningful. The augmented ratio adds Buybacks to the Dividends in the numerator.

Returns

\[\text{Retention Ratio} = 1 - \text{Dividend Payout Ratio} = \frac{\text{Retained Earnings}}{\text{Net Income}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.dividend_coverage_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = '', deduct_preferred_dividends: bool = True, use_augmented_ratio: bool = False)¶

The dividend coverage ratio is the ratio of company’s earnings (net income) over the dividend paid to shareholders, calculated as net profit or loss attributable to ordinary shareholders by total ordinary dividend.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • use_augmented_ratio –

  • deduct_preferred_dividends –

Returns

\[\text{Dividend Coverage Ratio} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Dividends}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.dividend_yield(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', diluted_shares: bool = False)¶

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.earnings_per_share(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', diluted_shares: bool = False, use_income_from_operations: bool = False, deduct_preferred_dividends: bool = True, weighted_average_shares: bool = True, as_reported: bool = True)¶

The earnings per share ratio measures the amount of net income earned for each share outstanding

Category: Market Value Ratios Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Notes: Compared with Earnings per share, a company’s cash flow is better indicator of the company’s earnings power. If a company’s earnings per share is less than cash flow per share over long term, investors need to be cautious and find out why.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • as_reported – outputs the EPS as reported by the company in the 10-K or 10-Q filing.

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

  • use_income_from_operations – Use income from continuing operations instead of Net Income in the numerator.

  • deduct_preferred_dividends –

  • weighted_average_shares – It is more accurate to use a weighted average number of common shares over the reporting term because the number of shares can change over time.

Returns

\[\text{Earnings Per Share} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Shares Outstanding}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.price_to_earnings(stock, date=datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 29, 11, 1, 42, 282443), lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', diluted_shares: bool = False, use_income_from_operations=False, deduct_preferred_dividends=True)¶

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.greenblatt_earnings_yield(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'FY')¶

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.price_to_earnings_to_growth(stock, date=datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 29, 11, 1, 42, 282443), lookback_period=datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', growth_periods: int = 5, diluted_shares: bool = False, use_income_from_operations: bool = False, deduct_preferred_dividends: bool = True)¶

The price/earnings to growth ratio (or PEG ratio) is a valuation metric for determining the relative trade-off between the price of a stock, the earnings generated per share (EPS), and the company’s expected growth.

Category: Market Value Ratios

Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Notes:

  • In general, the P/E ratio is higher for a company with a higher growth rate. Thus, using just the P/E ratio would make high-growth companies appear overvalued relative to others. It is assumed that by dividing the P/E ratio by the earnings growth rate, the resulting ratio is better for comparing companies with different growth rates. Therefore, a lower ratio is “better” (cheaper) and a higher ratio is “worse” (expensive).

  • According to Peter Lynch in his book One Up on Wall Street, the P/E ratio of any company that’s fairly priced will equal its growth rate”, i.e., a fairly valued company will have its PEG equal to 1.

  • The P/E ratio used in the calculation may be projected or trailing. The (annual) growth rate is expressed as a percent value, and should use real growth only, to correct for inflation. It may be the expected growth rate for the next year or the next five years.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • growth_periods –

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

  • use_income_from_operations –

  • deduct_preferred_dividends –

Returns

\[\text{} = \frac{\text{}}{\text{}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.book_value_per_share(stock, date=datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 29, 11, 1, 42, 282443), lookback_period=datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q', diluted_shares: bool = False, tangible=False)¶

The book value per share ratio calculates the per-share value of a company based on equity available to shareholders

Category: Market Value Ratios

Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

  • tangible –

Returns

\[\text{Book Value Per Share} = \frac{\text{Shareholder's Equity}}{\text{Total Shares Outstanding}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.price_to_book_ratio(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'Q', diluted_shares: bool = False, tangible_book_value: bool = False)¶

The price-to-book ratio (or P/B ratio) is used to compare a company’s current market capitalization to its book value; or, equivalently, divide the per-share stock price by the per-share book value.

Category: Market Value Ratios

Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Notes:

  • A higher P/B ratio implies that investors expect management to create more value from a given set of assets, all else equal (and/or that the market value of the firm’s assets is significantly higher than their accounting value). P/B ratios do not, however, directly provide any information on the ability of the firm to generate profits or cash for shareholders.

  • As with most ratios, it varies a fair amount by industry. Industries that require more infrastructure capital (for each dollar of profit) will usually trade at P/B ratios much lower than, for example, consulting firms. P/B ratios are commonly used to compare banks, because most assets and liabilities of banks are constantly valued at market values.

  • This ratio also gives some idea of whether an investor is paying too much for what would be left if the company went bankrupt immediately. For companies in distress, the book value is usually calculated without the intangible assets that would have no resale value. In such cases, P/B should also be calculated on a “diluted” basis, because stock options may well vest on sale of the company or change of control or firing of management.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

  • tangible_book_value – P/B can be calculated either including or excluding intangible assets and goodwill. When intangible assets and goodwill are excluded, the ratio is often specified to be “price to tangible book value”

Returns

\[\text{Price-to-Book Ratio} = \frac{\text{Market Capitalization}}{\text{Book Value}} = \frac{\text{Share Price}}{\text{Book Value per Share}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.price_to_sales(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', diluted_shares: bool = False)¶

Price–sales ratio (or P/S ratio, or PSR) is used to compare a company’s current market capitalization and the revenue in the most recent year; or, equivalently, divide the per-share stock price by the per-share revenue.

Category: Market Value Ratios

Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Notes:

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations. use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

Returns

\[\text{Price-to-Sales Ratio} = \frac{\text{Market Capitalization}}{\text{Revenue}} = \frac{\text{Share Price}}{\text{Per-Share Revenue}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.justified_price_to_sales(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM', diluted_shares: bool = False)¶

The justified P/S ratio is calculated as the price-to-sales ratio based on the Gordon Growth Model. Thus, it is the price-to-sales ratio based on the company’s fundamentals rather than . Here, g is the sustainable growth rate as defined below and r is the required rate of return.

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

  • diluted_shares – use diluted shares instead of basic in calculations.

Returns

\[\text{Justified P/S} = \text{Profit Margin} * \text{Payout} * \frac{1+g}{r-g} where .. math:: g = \text{Retention Ratio} * \text{Net Profit Margin} * \frac{\text{Sales}}{\text{Assets}} * \frac{\text{Assets}}{\text{Shareholders' Equity}}\]

fundamental_analysis.accounting_ratios.enterprise_value_to_revenue(stock, date=None, lookback_period: datetime.timedelta = datetime.timedelta(0), period: str = 'TTM')¶

The enterprise value-to-revenue multiple is a measure of the value of a stock that compares a company’s enterprise value to its revenue. It is often used to determine a company’s valuation in the case of a potential acquisition, and can be used for companies that do not generate income or profits.

Category: Enterprise Value Ratios

Subcategory: Equity Value Ratios

Parameters

  • stock – ticker(s) in question. Can be a string (i.e. ‘AAPL’) or a list of strings (i.e. [‘AAPL’, ‘BA’]).

  • date – Can be a datetime (i.e. datetime(2019, 1, 1)) or list of datetimes. The most recent date of reporting from that date will be used. By default, date=datetime.now().

  • lookback_period – lookback from date (used to compare against previous year or quarter etc.) i.e. timedelta(days=90).

  • period – ‘FY’ for fiscal year, ‘Q’ for quarter, ‘YTD’ for calendar year to date, ‘TTM’ for trailing twelve months.

Returns
